t: Song of Solomon 8
Longing for Her Beloved
Oh*pn that you were like a brother to me who*ld nursed at my mother’s breasts! If*ln I found you outside, I would kiss you, and*ld none would despise me.
I*ln would lead you and bring you into*ld the house of my mother— she*ld who used to teach me. I*ln would give you spiced wine to drink, the*ld juice of my pomegranate.
His*ln left hand is under my head, and*ld his right hand embraces me!
I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, that*ld you not stir up or awaken love until*ld it pleases.
Who*pn is that coming up from the wilderness, leaning*ld on her beloved? Under*pn the apple tree I awakened you. There*ln your mother was in labor with you; there*ld she who bore you was in labor.

Set*pn me as a seal upon your heart, as*ld a seal upon your arm, for*ln love is strong as death, jealousy*ld is fierce as the grave. Its*ln flashes are flashes of fire, the*ld very flame of the Lord.*s
Many*ln waters cannot quench love, neither*ld can floods drown it. If*ln a man offered for love all*ld the wealth of his house, he*ld would be utterly despised.
Final Advice
Others
We*pn have a little sister, and*ld she has no breasts. What*ln shall we do for our sister on*ld the day when she is spoken for?
If*ln she is a wall, we*ld will build on her a battlement of silver, but*ln if she is a door, we*ld will enclose her with boards of cedar.
She
I*pn was a wall, and*ld my breasts were like towers; then*ln I was in his eyes as*ld one who finds peace.
Solomon*pn had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; he*ld let out the vineyard to keepers; each*ld one was to bring for its fruit a thousand pieces of silver.
My*ln vineyard, my very own, is before me; you,*ld O Solomon, may have the thousand, and*ld the keepers of the fruit two hundred.
He
O*pn you who dwell in the gardens, with*ld companions listening for your voice; let*ld me hear it.
She
Make*pn haste, my beloved, and*ld be like a gazelle or*ln a young stag on*ld the mountains of spices.
